author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: 5 celebrities that made career comebacks after controversy
text:
Kevork Djansezian/Getty Images Actor Columbus Short made headlines when he was fired from "Scandal" after allegedly attacking his wife. Actor Columbus Short announced he’s making a comeback after getting booted from “Scandal” for allegedly attacking his wife and is slated to appear in the upcoming film, “True to the Game.”
But Short, if his role in the movie is successful, is only one of many celebrities who have bounced back into the spotlight after getting bad press.
Here are five celebrities that have made miracle career revivals after getting his or her name dragged in the mud:
Robert Downey Jr. Bertrand Rindoff Petroff/Getty Images After several run-ins with the law, Robert Downey, Jr. made his way back to the spotlight after starring in major motion pictures. Robert Downey, Jr. hasn't always had superpowers.
The "Iron Man" actor was fired from several movies in the late 1990s due to his drug and alcohol addiction and constant run-ins with the law — including a three-year prison stint for missing a scheduled drug test.
Downey has been sober since 2003 and has topped the Forbes list of Hollywood's highest-paid actors for three years in a row, after scoring box office gold appearing in "The Avengers" and "The Judge."
Michael Vick Paul Sancya/AP NFL quarterback Michael Vick continued to make touchdowns after serving jail time for illegal dog fighting. Michael Vick’s career took a nose dive soon after the NFL quarterback was drafted in 2001.
Vick, who was once sued by a former girlfriend for allegedly spreading genital herpes, became notorious for making inappropriate gestures to fans. But his biggest downfall came in 2007, when he was convicted on charges stemming from operating an illegal dog fighting ring and was sentenced to 23 months in prison.
Since his release, Vick has signed to play for three different NFL teams — the Philadelphia Eagles, the New York Jets and is currently starting for the Pittsburgh Steelers while Ben Roethlisberger is injured.
Britney Spears ROBYN BECK/AFP/Getty Images Britney Spears bounced back from controversy and contuinued to rise to the top with her career. There was a time in pop superstar Britney Spears' life when her career was toxic.
She caused controversy in 2006, when she was caught driving with her son Sean on her lap. And the following year, Spears made headlines when she was randomly shaved her head with clippers at a Los Angles salon after leaving a drug rehab facility.
But the "Oops...I Did It Again" singer bounced back in no time and has since released four albums.
She’s also become a judge on singing competition, "The X Factor" and recently received a four-year residency show at Planet Hollywood Resort and Casino in Las Vegas.
Charlie Sheen NBC/NBCU Photo Bank via Getty Images Actor Charlie Sheen is back to "winning" by staying out of trouble these days. It wasn’t long ago that Charlie Sheen wasn’t winning.
After being dismissed from the hit show "Two and a Half Men" for publicly making derogatory comments about the show's creator, Sheen spiraled out of control and had a public meltdown.
He’s since recovered from the days of calling himself a “warlock” and drinking “tiger’s blood.”
The Golden Globe winner has starred in the television show "Anger Management" and was roasted on Comedy Central.
Chris Brown Michael Tran/FilmMagic Talented artist Chris Brown danced his way back into the hearts of fans after several run-ins with law enforcement. R&B singer Chris Brown shocked fans when he turned in his good boy image for bad boy status.
Brown made headlines starting in 2009, when he surrendered to authorities for assaulting his then-girlfriend, singer Rihanna.
He caused another commotion in 2011, when he damaged a "Good Morning America" dressing room during a violent range over a question asked by anchor Robin Roberts.
After he received forgiveness from his fans, the Grammy Award-winning singer managed to release four number one albums and has made appearances in movies like "Think Like a Man."
